type_of_test: X-ray diffraction, Vickers hardness, compression tests
evidence: The crystal structures of both alloys are identified to be BCC structure (cI2-W). The lattice constants of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys were determined from the XRD peaks to be a HfMoTaTiZr ¼ 3.376 Å and a HfMoNbTaTiZr ¼ 3.370 Å, respectively. The theoretical densities of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys are 10.21 g/cm 3 and 9.95 g/cm 3 , respectively. These values are also close to the experimental values, d HfMoTaTiZr ¼ 10.24 g/cm 3 and d HfMoNbTaTiZr ¼ 9.97 g/cm 3 .

type_of_test: X-ray diffraction, Vickers hardness, compression tests
evidence: The crystal structures of both alloys are identified to be BCC structure (cI2-W). The lattice constants of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys were determined from the XRD peaks to be a HfMoTaTiZr ¼ 3.376 Å and a HfMoNbTaTiZr ¼ 3.370 Å, respectively. The theoretical densities of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys are 10.21 g/cm 3 and 9.95 g/cm 3 , respectively. These values are also close to the experimental values, d HfMoTaTiZr ¼ 10.24 g/cm 3 and d HfMoNbTaTiZr ¼ 9.97 g/cm 3 .

The yield strength of the HfMoTaTiZr alloy at RT is 1600 MPa. The Vickers hardness of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys are Hv 542 and Hv 505, respectively. Both alloys show typical cast dendritic structure.

The yield strength of the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy at RT is 1512 MPa. The Vickers hardness of the HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys are Hv 542 and Hv 505, respectively. Both alloys show typical cast dendritic structure.

microstructure: dendrite/interdendrites are elongated along directions inclined at ~55 to the compression direction. This is related to the formation of shear bands. Both vertical and inclined cracks are seen. Inclined cracks originate from the highly localized strain in the shear bands. For vertical cracks, the cause is the high lateral tensile stress induced by the compression. At 1000 C, the grains experience more compressive deformation and some shear bands are also formed (marked by dash line). Besides, a small number of cavities are seen to form in the shear bands. Unlike the HfMoTaTiZr alloy, no second phases formed during deformation are found in HfMoNbTaTiZr at 1000 C, at least by the observation of SEM. Therefore, the precipitation temperature is lower in HfMoNbTaTiZr. Compression at 1200 C leads to a significant amount of plastic flow, which squashes the cast dendritic structures. However, no cavities are discovered. Higher magnification images in Fig.  8(d ) reveal the formation of (Zr, Hf)-rich (black contrast) and Mo-rich (white contrast) precipitates in highly deformed interdendrite region. The diameter of (Zr, Hf)-rich precipitates are 300 nm whereas that of Mo-rich ones are 160 nm, both of which are smaller than the precipitates in HfMoTaTiZr alloy at 1200 C.
evidence: The microstructures of the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy after compression at different temperatures are shown in Fig.  8 . The loading direction is the vertical axis. After compression at 800 C, some dendrite/interdendrites are elongated along directions inclined at ~55 to the compression direction. This is related to the formation of shear bands. Both vertical and inclined cracks are seen. Inclined cracks originate from the highly localized strain in the shear bands. For vertical cracks, the cause is the high lateral tensile stress induced by the compression. At 1000 C, the grains experience more compressive deformation and some shear bands are also formed (marked by dash line). Besides, a small number of cavities are seen to form in the shear bands. Unlike the HfMoTaTiZr alloy, no second phases formed during deformation are found in HfMoNbTaTiZr at 1000 C, at least by the observation of SEM. Therefore, the precipitation temperature is lower in HfMoNbTaTiZr. Compression at 1200 C leads to a significant amount of plastic flow, which squashes the cast dendritic structures. However, no cavities are discovered. Higher magnification images in Fig.  8(d ) reveal the formation of (Zr, Hf)-rich (black contrast) and Mo-rich (white contrast) precipitates in highly deformed interdendrite region. The diameter of (Zr, Hf)-rich precipitates are 300 nm whereas that of Mo-rich ones are 160 nm, both of which are smaller than the precipitates in HfMoTaTiZr alloy at 1200 C.

microstructure: BCC structure with Mo-rich and (Zr, Hf)-rich precipitates in the interdendrite regions
evidence: Two new refractory HEAs, HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr, were designed based on the HfNbTaTiZr alloy in order to improve the overall properties. Several findings are drawn: (1) Both alloys have simple BCC structure. The lattice constants and densities of the two alloys are close to the values obtained by rule-of-mixture. In contrast, the hardnesses of both alloys are about three times higher than the rule-of-mixture values. This suggests a strong solid-solution strengthening. (2) The compression yield strengths of the HfMoTaTiZr alloy at RT, 800, 1000, and 1200 C are 1600, 1045, 855, and 339 MPa, respectively. The corresponding values for the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy are 1512, 1007, 814, and 556 MPa, respectively. (3) The fracture strain of the HfMoTaTiZr alloy is 4% and that for the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy is 12% at RT. The fracture surfaces of the two alloys suggest that the fracture mode is mixture of cleavage and quasi-cleavage. Less cleavage fracture features are observed in the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy. (4) As temperature increases, the yield strengths of the alloys decrease while plastic strains increase. The combination of strength and plasticity for the HfMoNbTaTiZr alloy is better than that of HfMoTaTiZr at all test temperatures. During the compression at 1000 C (for HfMoTaTiZr) or 1200 C (for both alloys), Mo-rich and (Zr, Hf)-rich precipitates form in the interdendrite regions. The crystal structure of the (Zr, Hf)rich precipitate is FCC, which is different from the prediction of binary phase diagram. (5) Compared with the base alloy (HfNbTaTiZr), the strengths of the two modified alloys at elevated temperatures are markedly higher. The yield strength of HfMoNbTaTiZr is more than six times that of HfNbTaTiZr at 1200 C. The yield strength values are higher than that of Inconel 718 and CMSX-4 at all testing temperatures except for CMSX-4 at 800 C. The
